awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH:   Blood meal source as an ecological determinant of bacterial community dynamics in the tick vector AMBLYOMMA AMERICANUM
awd_abstract_narration:
A key obstacle to understanding the ecology of tick-borne diseases is the identification of the specific vertebrate animals, or hosts, on which ticks feed. Each host is potentially important because different species contain different combinations of nutrients, immune system molecules, and microbes that can affect pathogen transmission by the ticks. This doctoral dissertation improvement project will adapt existing molecular techniques to amplify trace remains of DNA from previous tick blood meals in order to determine past host use. Gene sequencing methods will then be used to determine the effect of prior hosts on the composition of bacterial communities in host-seeking ticks. This information will help to explain variation in bacterial communities among ticks and to predict the abundance and distribution of infectious ticks in the environment. Assay development and testing will use the lone star tick, the most common tick biting humans and animals in two thirds of the continental USA. It is the known vector of several human and veterinary pathogens and the carrier of many other bacteria whose significance in disease transmission is not well understood.

Development of a new approach to blood meal analysis will provide a valuable tool to all researchers who study the ecology of blood-feeding arthropods, such as many medically and economically important tick species.  The assay improves efficiency by exploiting recent advances in DNA sequencing technology to establish and increase sample throughput. The project will train undergraduate students in field and laboratory research involving both ecological and molecular methods. Finally, the researchers present their results to the staff and visitors to several Georgia state parks.

por.por_cntn:
Tick-borne diseases affect tens of thousands of people in the United States annually and many more animals. Ticks may acquire some pathogens from the wildlife and domestic animals they feed upon, while others are passed from female to offspring or tick to tick during blood feeding. Predicting the relative risk of contracting a tick-borne disease in a given location is difficult for many reasons, one of which is a lack of information about which animal hosts are most frequently associated with each of the many different pathogens transmitted by ticks. This research advanced the development of new assays that will allow faster and more precise identification of vertebrate hosts used by ticks for blood meals without the need for labor-intensive host species-specific capture methods. These new assays depend upon the detection of blood meal DNA and proteins within questing ticks seeking new hosts.

Motivated by and benefitting from the Barcode of Life project, we screened several different avian and mammalian mitochondrial genes as potential DNA “mini-barcodes”. These extremely variable regions of DNA can be used to identify the species of animal from which they originated. Their short length increases the probability that they will remain intact within the tick even after blood meal digestion, and because there are many copies of the mitochondrial genome per animal cell, there are more targets available for the assay to detect. An alternative method of detecting blood proteins unique to each host using mass spectrometry is also under investigation.

Currently, we are completing the process of testing the new DNA assays in the laboratory. Early experiments have demonstrated the ability of the assays to detect bird or mammal DNA alone or when the DNA is mixed with the DNA of ticks and the bacteria that they carry. One remaining experiment is to test the assay against ticks that have been held many months without feeding. In the wild, ticks may live many months between feedings and studies have previously shown that blood meals become harder to detect as the tick ages without feeding. We are currently collecting tick samples from a laboratory colony to test the efficacy of the mammalian assay in ticks up to one year post-feeding.

The blood meal assays have been designed using the lone star tick (Amblyomma americanum) as the target tick species. We chose the lone star tick because it is an abundant and aggressive biter of humans, wildlife, and domestic animals throughout much of the contiguous United States. As its range expands north and west, increasing numbers of people are potentially exposed to this tick and the pathogens it transmits. However, despite being developed with the lone star tick, we have found that these blood DNA assays also work with other tick species. These assays therefore provide a tool for researchers to gain a better understanding of the host use and pathogen acquisition of many tick species that will inform future tick control efforts. When assay development is completed, Co-PI Williams-Newkirk will be using the assays to relate whole tick bacterial communities – both pathogens and tick commensals – characterized by Next-Gen sequencing to past host use as a part of her dissertation research on the bacterial community ecology of the lone star tick.

Three junior students contributed to this research, including two undergraduates and one Master of Public Health student from Emory University. All three students received extensive training in assay design, DNA extraction, and assay execution. One undergraduate student presented a portion of the research at an Emory student research poster session, providing the first such opportunity for this student to prepare a poster and present research in a public forum.
